prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
# IRAS 08572+3915 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Based on our ALMA Cycle 0 data, the HCN J=4-3 peak flux of IRAS 08572+3915 is estimated to be 10 mJy (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014 AJ 148 9). When HCN is thermally-excited at up to J=4-3, the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 9/16 of the HCN J=4-3 peak flux (i.e., 5.5 mJy). When HCN J=4-3 is sub-thermally excited, the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is larger than 9/16 of the HCN J=4-3 peak flux (i.e., >5.5 mJy).
On the other hand, it is known that HCN J=1-0 and infrared (8-1000 micron) luminosity (flux) correlate well for Galactic and extra-galactic dusty active regions (Gao & Solomon 2004 ApJS 152 63; Wu et al. 2005 ApJ 635 L173). Based on our pre-ALMA interferometric data, we also found the correlation between HCN J=1-0 peak flux from ULIRG's nuclei and galaxy-wide infrared flux measured with IRAS's large aperture (Figure 3 of this proposal). This correlation again supports the scenario that ULIRG's dominant energy sources are located in nuclear regions. We can convert the IRAS-measured infrared (8-1000 micron) flux to HCN J=1-0 emission peak flux, using the dashed line in Figure 3. If we assume thermal excitation of HCN at up to J=4-3, then the expected HCN J=4-3 emission peak flux is about 50 mJy in IRAS 08572+3915. The observed HCN J=4-3 peak flux of 10 mJy is only 1/5 of the expected flux for thermal excitation, suggesting that the HCN emission is only subthermally-excited at J=4-3. Thus, we can safely adopt >5.5 mJy as the HCN J=3-2 peak flux of IRAS 08572+3915.
We set the required 1 sigma noise level to be 1.0 mJy so that we can detect the peak flux with >5 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (5.5 mJy).
Since the primary aim of this proposal is to compare the flux ratios among HCN, HCO+, and HNC, we need data of HCO+ J=3-2 and HNC J=3-2. Using ALMA, we can observe HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 simultaneously. At J=4-3, the HCN-to-HCO+ flux ratio in IRAS 08572+3915 is 0.8 (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014). With the 1.0 mJy noise level, we can distinguish clearly whether the HCN-to-HCO+ flux ratio at J=3-2 is similar to or larger (smaller) than 0.8. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that 0.5 hr is needed to achieve the 1.0 mJy noise level with the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
This observation is included in our accepted ALMA Cycle 2 program (2013.1.00032.S), but has not been executed in Cycle 2, as of writing this proposal. Given the right ascension = 8 hr and declination = +40 degree of this object, this observation is unlikely to be conducted during the remaining period of Cycle 2. Thus, we include this observation in this ALMA Cycle 3 proposal. If the observation is conducted during the remaining period of ALMA Cycle 2, we need not repeat the same observation in ALMA Cycle 3.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate less than 6 MB/s.

To pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in apparent size) and probe the putative AGN feedback to molecular line flux ratios, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst emission, we request <1.0 arcsec angular resolution. Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >3 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-6 observation using the C36-2, C36-3, C36-4, or C36-5 configuration (without ACA) between 2016 March and July, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 12127-1412 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Based on our ALMA Cycle 0 data, the HCN J=4-3 peak flux of IRAS 12127-1412 is estimated to be 3 mJy (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014). When HCN is thermally-excited at up to J=4-3, the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 9/16 of the HCN J=4-3 peak flux (i.e., 1.7 mJy). When HCN J=4-3 is sub-thermally excited, the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is larger than 9/16 of the HCN J=4-3 peak flux (i.e., >1.7 mJy).
On the other hand, it is known that HCN J=1-0 and infrared (8-1000 micron) luminosity (flux) correlate well for Galactic and extra-galactic dusty active regions (Gao & Solomon 2004; Wu et al. 2005). Based on our pre-ALMA interferometric data, we also found the correlation between HCN J=1-0 peak flux from ULIRG's nuclei and galaxy-wide infrared flux measured with IRAS's large aperture (Figure 3 of this proposal). This correlation again supports the scenario that ULIRG's dominant energy sources are located in nuclear regions. We can convert the IRAS-measured infrared (8-1000 micron) flux to HCN J=1-0 emission peak flux, using the dashed line in Figure 3. If we assume thermal excitation of HCN at up to J=4-3, then the expected HCN J=4-3 emission peak flux is about 15 mJy in IRAS 12127-1412. The observed HCN J=4-3 peak flux of 3 mJy is only 1/5 of the expected flux for thermal excitation, suggesting that the HCN emission is only subthermally-excited at J=4-3. Thus, we can safely adopt >1.7 mJy as the HCN J=3-2 peak flux of IRAS 12127-1412.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.9 hr observing time, 0.5 mJy noise level is achieved, with the 20 km/s velocity resolution. With this noise level, we should be able to detect the HCN J=3-2 peak flux with >3 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (1.7 mJy). Since the velocity width of HCN emission from IRAS 12127-1412 is much larger than 20 km/s (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014), at least a few consecutive spectral elements near the peak should show >3 sigma excess. Based on spectral fitting and/or integrated intensity (moment 0) map, we should be able to detect HCN J=3-2 emission with >5 sigma (e.g., Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014).
HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines are observable simultaneously.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate less than 6 MB/s.

To pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in apparent size) and probe the putative AGN feedback to molecular line flux ratios, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst emission, we request <1.0 arcsec angular resolution. Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >3 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-6 observation using the C36-2, C36-3, C36-4, or C36-5 configuration (without ACA) between 2016 March and July, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 13451+1232 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We estimate the expected HCN J=1-0 flux from the IRAS-measured infrared flux (Figure 3, dashed line). Assuming thermal excitation, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 15 mJy for IRAS 13451+1232. Our ALMA Cycle 0 observations show that HCN J=4-3 emission is often only sub-thermally excited even in active ULIRGs hosting luminous buried AGNs (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014). We thus consider the case that the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. This assumption is conservative, because excitation at J=3-2 should be closer to thermal than at J=4-3. Namely, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux of IRAS 13451+1232 is 3-15 mJy.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.7 hr observing time, 0.7 mJy noise level is achieved, with the 20 km/s velocity resolution. With this noise level, we should be able to detect the HCN J=3-2 peak flux with >4 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (3 mJy). Since the velocity width of HCN emission from IRAS 13451+1232 should be much larger than 20 km/s, at least a few consecutive spectral elements near the peak should show >4 sigma excess. Based on spectral fitting and/or integrated intensity (moment 0) map, we should be able to detect HCN J=3-2 emission with >5 sigma.
HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines are observable simultaneously.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate less than 6 MB/s.

To pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in apparent size) and probe the putative AGN feedback to molecular line flux ratios, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst emission, we request <1.0 arcsec angular resolution. Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >3 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-6 observation using the C36-2, C36-3, C36-4, or C36-5 configuration (without ACA) between 2016 March and July, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 06035-7102 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We estimate the expected HCN J=1-0 flux from the IRAS-measured infrared flux (Figure 3, dashed line). Assuming thermal excitation, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 25 mJy for IRAS 06035-7102. Our ALMA Cycle 0 observations show that HCN J=4-3 emission is often only sub-thermally excited even in active ULIRGs hosting luminous buried AGNs (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014). We thus consider the case that the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. This assumption is conservative, because excitation at J=3-2 should be closer to thermal than at J=4-3. Namely, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux of IRAS 06035-7102 is 5-25 mJy.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.6 hr observing time, 0.8 mJy noise level is achieved, with the 20 km/s velocity resolution. With this noise level, we should be able to detect the HCN J=3-2 peak flux with >6 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (5 mJy).
HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines are observable simultaneously.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate less than 6 MB/s.

To pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in apparent size) and probe the putative AGN feedback to molecular line flux ratios, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst emission, we request <1.0 arcsec angular resolution. Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >3 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-6 observation using the C36-2, C36-3, C36-4, or C36-5 configuration (without ACA) between 2016 March and July, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 15250+3609 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We estimate the expected HCN J=1-0 flux from the IRAS-measured infrared flux (Figure 3, dashed line). Assuming thermal excitation, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 35 mJy for IRAS 15250+3609. Our ALMA Cycle 0 observations show that HCN J=4-3 emission is often only sub-thermally excited even in active ULIRGs hosting luminous buried AGNs (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014). We thus consider the case that the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. This assumption is conservative, because excitation at J=3-2 should be closer to thermal than at J=4-3. Namely, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux of IRAS 15250+3609 is 7-35 mJy.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.6 hr observing time, 0.9 mJy noise level is achieved, with the 20 km/s velocity resolution. With this noise level, we should be able to detect the HCN J=3-2 peak flux with >7 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (7 mJy).
HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines are observable simultaneously.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate less than 6 MB/s.

Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >3 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-6 observation using the C36-2, C36-3, C36-4, or C36-5 configuration (without ACA) between 2016 March and July, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 20414-1651 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We estimate the expected HCN J=1-0 flux from the IRAS-measured infrared flux (Figure 3, dashed line). Assuming thermal excitation, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 20 mJy for IRAS 20414-1651. Our ALMA Cycle 0 observations show that HCN J=4-3 emission is often only sub-thermally excited even in active ULIRGs hosting luminous buried AGNs (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014). We thus consider the case that the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. This assumption is conservative, because excitation at J=3-2 should be closer to thermal than at J=4-3. Namely, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux of IRAS 20414-1651 is 4-20 mJy.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, 0.8 mJy noise level is achieved, with the 20 km/s velocity resolution. With this noise level, we should be able to detect the HCN J=3-2 peak flux with >5 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (4 mJy).
HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines are simultaneously observable.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate less than 6 MB/s.

Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >3 arcsec. We request single pointing band 6 observation using the C36-2, C36-3, C36-4, or C36-5 configuration (without ACA) between 2016 March and June, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 13509+0442 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We estimate the expected HCN J=1-0 flux from the IRAS-measured infrared flux (Figure 3, dashed line). Assuming thermal excitation, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 10 mJy for IRAS 13509+0442. Our ALMA Cycle 0 observations show that HCN J=4-3 emission is often only sub-thermally excited even in active ULIRGs hosting luminous buried AGNs (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014). We thus consider the case that the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. This assumption is conservative, because excitation at J=3-2 should be closer to thermal than at J=4-3. Namely, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux of IRAS 13509+0442 is 2-10 mJy.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.8 hr observing time, 0.6 mJy noise level is achieved, with the 20 km/s velocity resolution. With this noise level, we should be able to detect the HCN J=3-2 peak flux with >3 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (2 mJy). Since the velocity width of HCN emission from IRAS 13509+0442 should be much larger than 20 km/s, at least a few consecutive spectral elements near the peak should show >3 sigma excess. Based on spectral fitting and/or integrated intensity (moment 0) map, we should be able to detect HCN J=3-2 emission with >5 sigma.
HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines are observable simultaneously.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate less than 6 MB/s.

To pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in apparent size) and probe the putative AGN feedback to molecular line flux ratios, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst emission, we request <1.0 arcsec angular resolution. Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >3 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-6 observation using the C36-2, C36-3, C36-4, or C36-5 configuration (without ACA) between 2016 March and July, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 08572+3915 HNC J=3-2 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
While HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines are simultaneously observable with ALMA, we need separate observation of HNC J=3-2 line. To constrain the flux ratios among HCN/HCO+/HNC J=3-2 in IRAS 08572+3915, we set the same noise level (1.0 mJy) as employed for the HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 observation of IRAS 08572+3915, for this HNC J=3-2 observation. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 1.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
This observation is included in our accepted ALMA Cycle 2 program (2013.1.00032.S), but has not been executed in Cycle 2, as of writing this proposal. Given the right ascension = 8 hr and declination = +40 degree of this object, this observation is unlikely to be conducted during the remaining period of Cycle 2. Thus, we include this observation in this ALMA Cycle 3 proposal. If the observation is conducted during the remaining period of ALMA Cycle 2, we need not repeat the same observation in ALMA Cycle 3.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=3-2 and HNC v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to estimate the possible continuum spectral index and to better understand the physical origin of the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate about 6 MB/s.

To pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in apparent size) and probe the putative AGN feedback to molecular line flux ratios, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst emission, we request <1.0 arcsec angular resolution. Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >3 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-6 observation using the C36-2, C36-3, C36-4, or C36-5 configuration (without ACA) between 2016 March and July, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.9 hr observing time, we can achieve 0.5 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=3-2 and HNC v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to estimate the possible continuum spectral index and to better understand the physical origin of the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate about 6 MB/s.

To pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in apparent size) and probe the putative AGN feedback to molecular line flux ratios, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst emission, we request <1.0 arcsec angular resolution. Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >3 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-6 observation using the C36-2, C36-3, C36-4, or C36-5 configuration (without ACA) between 2016 March and July, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 13509+0442 HNC J=3-2 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
While HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines are simultaneously observable with ALMA, we need separate observation of HNC J=3-2 line. To constrain the flux ratios among HCN/HCO+/HNC J=3-2 in IRAS 13509+0442, we set the same noise level (0.6 mJy) as employed for the HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 observation of IRAS 13509+0442, for this HNC J=3-2 observation. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.8 hr observing time, we can achieve 0.6 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=3-2 and HNC v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to estimate the possible continuum spectral index and to better understand the physical origin of the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines.

# IRAS 13451+1232 HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 # (HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 data of IRAS 08572+3915 and 12127-1412 have been taken in our ALMA Cycle 0 program (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014), and so their observations are not requested in this Cycle 3 proposal.)
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
The expected HCN J=4-3 peak flux from (1) the HCN J=1-0 peak flux converted from the IRAS-measured infrared flux (Figure 3) and (2) assumption for thermal excitation, is 25 mJy. We also consider the case that HCN J=4-3 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. We adopt 5-25 mJy as the HCN J=4-3 peak flux of IRAS 13451+1232.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.7 hr observing time, we can achieve 1.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
HCO+ J=4-3 line is simultaneously observable with HCN J=4-3.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=4-3 and HCO+ J=4-3 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate about 6 MB/s.

To pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in apparent size) and probe the putative AGN feedback to molecular line flux ratios, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst emission, we request <1.0 arcsec angular resolution. Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >2.5 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-7 observation using the C36-1, C36-2, C36-3, or C36-4 configuration (without ACA) between 2015 December and 2016 May, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 20414-1651 HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
The expected HCN J=4-3 peak flux from (1) the HCN J=1-0 peak flux converted from the IRAS-measured infrared flux (Figure 3) and (2) assumption for thermal excitation, is 35 mJy. We also consider the case that HCN J=4-3 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. We adopt 7-35 mJy as the HCN J=4-3 peak flux of IRAS 20414-1651.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.9 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.1 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution. Since the velocity width of HCN emission from IRAS 20414-1651 should be much larger than 20 km/s, at least a few consecutive spectral elements near the peak should show >3 sigma excess. Based on spectral fitting and/or integrated intensity (moment 0) map, we should be able to detect HCN J=4-3 emission with >5 sigma.
HCO+ J=4-3 line is simultaneously observable with HCN J=4-3.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.

# IRAS 08572+3915 HNC J=4-3 # (HNC J=4-3 data of IRAS 12127-1412 have been taken in our ALMA Cycle 0 program (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2014), and so this observation is not requested in this Cycle 3 proposal.)
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
The achieved 1 sigma noise level for our ALMA Cycle 0 HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 data of IRAS 08572+3915 is 2.0 mJy for 20 km/s velocity resolution. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.6 hr observing time, we can achieve 1.5 mJy noise level for HNC J=4-3 data, for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Although HNC J=4-3 observation of IRAS 08572+3915 was conducted in our ALMA Cycle 0 program (2011.0.00020.S), data were not provided to us because they did not pass the most basic quality checks. This observation is included in our accepted ALMA Cycle 2 program (2013.1.00032.S), but has not been executed in Cycle 2, as of writing this proposal, and is on the list of unlikely observed scheduling blocks in Cycle 2. We therefore include this observation in this ALMA Cycle 3 proposal. If the observation is conducted during the remaining period of ALMA Cycle 2, we need not repeat the same observation in ALMA Cycle 3.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=4-3 and HNC v2=1f J=4-3 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines.
By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate about 6 MB/s.

To pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in apparent size) and probe the putative AGN feedback to molecular line flux ratios, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst emission, we request <1.0 arcsec angular resolution. Since the spatial extent of our interesting nuclear molecular emission is at most a few arcsec, we set the maximum recoverable scale as >2.5 arcsec. We request single-pointing, band-7 observation using the C36-1, C36-2, C36-3, or C36-4 configuration (without ACA) between 2015 December and 2016 May, based on Table 3 of the ALMA Cycle 3 Proposer's Guide and Capabilities.

# IRAS 13451+1232 HNC J=4-3 #
We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.9 hr observing time, we can achieve 1.6 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution. This is similar to (but slightly higher than) the noise level of the HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 observation of IRAS 13451+1232, due to bad Earth's atmospheric transmission at the frequency of HNC J=4-3 line. If HNC J=4-3 peak flux is comparable to HCN J=4-3 peak flux, we should be able to detect HNC J=4-3 peak flux with >3 sigma. Since the velocity width of HNC emission from IRAS 13451+1232 should be much larger than 20 km/s, at least a few consecutive spectral elements near the peak should show >3 sigma excess. Based on spectral fitting and/or integrated intensity (moment 0) map, we should be able to detect HNC J=4-3 emission with >5 sigma.

We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution.

By adopting a spectral averaging factor of 4, we can make the data rate about 6 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose molecular line observations of nearby dust/gas-rich ultraluminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs) whose energy sources (AGN or starburst) are quantitatively well-calibrated through infrared spectroscopy. Our scientific goal is to establish a firm energy diagnostic method of dust/gas-rich galaxies, based on bright molecular line flux ratios at the dust-extinction-free (sub)millimeter wavelength range. It is suggested that enhanced HCN emission is empirically an excellent AGN indicator, but its validity and physical origin is still unclear. By combining with our ALMA Cycle 0 and 2 data, we aim to obtain molecular line flux ratios for multiple sources in each energy source category, at multiple transition lines of HCN/HCO+/HNC, to see the overall trend of molecular line flux ratios as a function of primary energy source, and to understand its physical origin. ALMA is best suited, because of (1) its high sensitivity and stable spectral baseline, and (2) its high spatial resolution to pinpoint AGN-affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei. Our data will be a valuable basis to interpret future ALMA molecular gas observational results of the cosmologically important ULIRG population.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is an extension of our accepted ALMA Cycle 0 (2011.0.00020.S) and Cycle 2 (2013.1.00032.S) programs (PI = M. Imanishi). If observations of our Cycle 2 program are conducted, we will be able to obtain data of up to one source in each energy source category. However, only two out of 15 science blocks have been observed in ALMA Cycle 2, as of writing this proposal.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
School of Physical Sciences, Graduate University for Advanced Studies
